And not only does prudence and charity for those who are dependent upon us require us to abstain from a perilous war, but often justice also, that is, rectorial justice3 which, from the very nature of governmcnt‚ binds the superior to care fot· the inferiors, no less than the inferiors to obey the superior. From which it follows, as theologians have observed, that a king who under- takes wars for light causes, or for the purpose of exacting punish- ments which are not necessary, and which bring great danger with them, is bound to his subjects for reparation of tho loss thence arising to them3 for if he do no injur-y to the enemy, he does one to his own suhjects, when, for such canses, he implicates them in so great evils.
